titleStmt.title: Tamiḻneṟi Viḷakkam 19.
Experimenting with formatting for the final edition.

witness.expan: A Critical Edition and Study of Akapporul Vilakkam [ante correctionem]
A Critical Edition and Study of Akapporul Vilakkam [post correctionem]

lg.l: [The heroine] thinking of the path by which [the hero] comes and saying, "Do not come!",
the desolate speech [of the confidante] on account of [the heroine's] imprisonment,
[the heroine] saying, "[You] ought to come.", [the heroine] saying, "Do not come!",
[the confidante] making things up, [the confidante] speaking of the excellence of [the hero's] family,
— they say that [these] and others which are suitably expressed, taken together,

div.p: The quoted [cūttiram] intends to make known the way in which 'asking for marriage' occurs.

āṟu pārttuṟṟa vaccak kiḷaviyum varavu vilakkaluṅ kāppiṉ iraṅkiya kaiyaṟu kiḷaviyum iraviṉum pakaliṉum nī vā veṉṟalum vāral eṉṟalum paṭaittu moḻitaluṅ kuṭit tiṟaṅ kūṟalumāṉiṭa makaḷ ātal iṉṟaṟintēṉ eṉṟalum eṉa viṉṉa vellām varaivu kaṭātal eṉṟu colluvar pulavar eṉṟa vāṟu.

The speech situation of experiencing fear having seen the path, averting the coming, the speech situation of desolation on account of the guarding, saying, "You come either in the day or night.", saying, "Do not come.", and saying, "I knew this woman as being honourable today." — the poet-scholars say all of these such [situations] are ‘asking for marriage’.

lg.l: You did not sayCould eṉṉāy have a similar rhetoric flavour to a negative imperative — "O, do not say...!"? that there are difficult things on the way,

where the swelling flood spreads and the rocks are tall.The idea is that there are rocks which protrude from the ground and make walking painful, I think, rather than there just being large rocks or boulders around.
Our lover will come in the night. I am not strong, O friend!

[How] will I live life?This understanding necessitates taking the particle -ē in vāḻvēṉ-ē as an interrogative. This is not the normal function at the end of a poem, however it is one of the accepted functions of the particle (see TC257).

div.p: [The heroine's] speech about [her] fear when thinking about [the hero's] path.

lg.l: Please don't come, O man from the land with mountain-slopes!

You, lonely man, faceThis is not the most literal translation for the phrase, ūṟutu uṭaiya. The idea is that he has an affliction waiting for him. This is a close but still idiomatic way to translate. a great obstacle
— the difficult desert, where the way is guardedāṟu kaṭi koḷḷum arum curam literally translates to: "The difficult desert, where the way takes protection (of the elephant)."

by small-eyed elephants which are killed by strong tigers.As in KT88, this phrase — uṟu puli koṉṟa ciṟu kaṇ yāṉai — is unmarked for case, however here the word order suggests that it is the tigers which kill the elephants. Possibly this flips that image to reinforce the danger the hero would face on the way.
Mother has forgotten sleep. On top of that,
the dogs and the town do not sleep at all.
And on top of that, the guards don't sleep.
And the moon with beautiful rays is in constantniṉṟu is understood here as 'continuing', however one could also translate: "the moon stands [there] shining". bloom.
What will become of the girl with the eminent jewels?

div.p: [The confidante'sThe situation isn't entirely clear. It could be the heroine speaking, though if that were the case, it would be odd for her to refer to herself in the third person.] speech about [the heroine's] overwhelming sadness, weeping because [she is under] guard.

lg.l: When you come onlyThis translates the emphatic particle -ē in pakalē. One could also understand a slightly different function, in which case: "in the middle of the day". Considering pakal iṉṟu in the next line, I think the translation of 'only' is most convincing as it provides the clearest counterpart. in the day, she is inconsolable.
And when you come at night but not by day, that is also [the case].
O man with the fragrant chest, say what is to be done!

div.p: eṉpatu iraviṉum pakaliṉum nī vā veṉṟatu.
[The confidante] says, "You come, either by day or night."

lg.l: When you come along this way in the day with the beautyOr simply, 'appearance'. of Murukaṉ,

we fear the scandal of our mixed nature.The semantics of viravu iyal kavvai are not clear. It could either refer to the scandal which concerns the hero and the heroine's union, or a scandal that itself is of a mixed and thus varied nature (i.e. random unfocused gossip).

But even more than that, if you come at night, we are terrified.peritu has essentially been translated as an intensifying adverb. Thus the base meaning of añcutum, 'to fear', becomes 'to be terrified'.

div.p: [The confidante] says, "Do not come, either by day or night."

lg.l: Yesterday, along this path through the backwaters and flowery seashore grove,
there was this one chariot. Thinking of it,

she staredOne can either understand peritu as above (intensively look = stare) or as a kind of predicate for house, in which case it would function similarly to an adjective — "she looked at the big thing, our house (i.e. at our large house)." destructively at our house.

Seeing the female elephant with its cloud-coloured male in rut,There are three different options for how to understand maḻai mata yāṉai. First option: as translated. Second option: "male elephant in rut under the rain", where maḻai means 'rain'. Third option: "male elephant with ichor raining [from it]", where maḻai is understood as an attribute of the elephant's musk.
playing under the waterfall on the bamboo-slope, with her doe-like eyes,
If you desire marriage, our people are readyLit., "they are at the right time.", i.e. they are primed to accept the marriage proposal.
The innocent daughter of the man from the forest

is alsoThe force of -um in pētaiyum is not obvious. In this translation, the daughter is, in addition to being her father's daughter, also a girl like any other. 'Still' or 'just' are more natural translations in English, but that moves away from the proscribed meanings of the particle. a foolish girl with a fragrant forehead and large shoulders.

div.p: [The confidante] talks about the issue of [her] family.

lg.l: We have taken this in and now we understand.
Until yesterday, we never thoughtLit., "we were without any thought of". Cf. NA27, 193 and 239 for parallel constructions to matittaṉṟō ilamē. of the girl
[as anything] apart from as a god
living on the great mountain which touches the moon.

standOff.note: Cf. TP164i.1: ...kaiyaru kiḷavi
Cf. IA30.2: kāppuc ciṟaimikka kaiyaṟu kiḷaviyum
Cf. TP207i.5: kiḻavōṉ ṟaṉṉai vāra lenṟalum |
Cf. IA30.5: kiḻavōṉ taṉṉai vāral enṟalum |
Cf. IA12.8: paṭaittumoḻi kiḷaviyum

The sitaution for which the TP employs this phrase is slightly different, but as this is the only time in the TP where this phrase is used, it is reasonable to expect that this would have been known to the author of this text. In the TP it refers to the desolation of an intermediary arguing for the hero to be allowed home after an affair.
Cf. IA30.3: āṟupārt tuṟṟa accak kiḷaviyum
Cf. AV164.11: āṟupārt tuṟṟa vaccak kiḷavi
Cf. AV164.14: neṟivilakku vittal
Cf. AV164.13: taṉṉuṭ kaiyā ṟeytiṭu kiḷavi
Cf. TP207i.4: iraviṉum pakaliṉu nīvā veṉṟaluṅ |
Cf. IA30.4: iraviṉum pakaliṉu nīvāru veṉṟalum |
Cf. AV166.6-8: pakalvaru vāṉai yiravuvaru keṉṟalum | iravuvaru vāṉai pakalvaru keṉṟalum | pakaṉum iraviṉum payiṉṟuvaru keṉṟal
The first two sitautions cited from the AV here resemble the content of the TNVC poem closely, and the final one the koḷu and the sources cited.
Cf. IAC30, p.149: talaimakaṉai iraviṉkaṇṇum pakaliṉkaṇṇum vāral eṉṟu collutal
Cf. AV166.9: pakaṉum iraviṉum akalivaṇ eṉṟal
Cf. IAC30, p.147: aḵtāmāṟu, talaimakaṉ iravukkuṟivantu oḻukāniṉṟa nilaimaikkaṇ, emporumāṉ varumvaḻi iṟappavum iṉṉātu, nīruṭaittu kalluṭaittu muḷḷuṭaittu ēṟṟuṭaittu iḻivuṭaittu eṉak kavaṟal,
Cf. Kali24.14: yāmuyir vāḻu matukai yilēm

nam kātalar is a very well established phrase to refer to the hero, and am kātalar, which would be the reading of the palm-leaf MS, occurs nowhere and though one could make sense of it, it would be a highly unlikely reading.

This final line bears some resemblence to Kali24.14, in terms of its meaning and context. Because of this similarity and the fact that uyir vāḻ-tal is normally preceded by a pronoun in the old akam corpus, UVC's reading is chosen. One can also make sense of the palm-leaf reading here: 'When our lover comes in the night, I am not strong, O friend! [How] will I live life?'.
Cf. KT88.2: ciṟukaṭ peruṅkaḷiṟu vayappuli tākkit
Cf. AN65.16-17: ... kōṭēn torutta | lāṟukaṭi koḷḷu maruñcuram
Cf. TK255.2-4: kuḻikaṭ kaḷiṟu verīiyari yāḷi kuḻīi vaḻaṅkāk | kaḻikaṭ ṭiraviṉ varalkaḻal kaitoḻu tēyirantēṉ | poḻikaṭ puyaliṉ mayiliṟ ṟuvaḷu mivaḷporuṭṭē||
Cf. PK220-227 also. These poems all treat this topic, though none in quite the same way as the TNVC verse. They are left unquoted due to space concerns and becuase none are an obvious direct source.
Cf. IAC30, p.145: ciṟaikāval eṉpatu, tāytuñcāmai

Cf. AN122.4-10:valluraik kaṭuñco laṉṉai tuñcāḷ | piṇikō ḷaruñciṟai yaṉṉai tuñciṟ | ṟuñcāk kaṇṇar kāvalar kaṭukuva | rilaṅkuvē liḷaiyar tuñciṉ vaiyeyiṟṟu | valañcurit tōkāi ñāḷi makiḻu | maravavāy ñamali makiḻātu maṭiyiṟ | pakaluru vuṟaḻanilāka kāṉṟu
Cf. PK215.2-3 (IAC30, p.145): ...maṭantaiyic cēyiḻaiyāḷ | tāyum tuyilmaṟan tāḷ
Cf. PK216.3-4 (IAC30, p.145): ...ūrum tuyiṉṟiṭam kāvala rōṭaṉṉai uḷḷuṟuttel | lārun tuyiliṉum tuñcā ñamali araiyiruḷē ||
Cf. PK217.4 (IAC30, p.145): ... tuñcā tiraviv viyaṉnakarē ||
Cf. PK218.3-4 (IAC30, p.146): ... vaḷnakar kākkumvai vēliḷaiñar | tuṭikkaṇ iraṇṭuṅkaṅ kultalai o+n+rum tuyiṉṟilavē ||
Cf. PK219.4 (IAC30, p.146): niṉṟu vicumpiṟ pakalpōl viriyum nilāmatiyē ||
Cf. TK175: iṉṉaṟa vārpoḻiṟ ṟillai nakariṟai cīrviḻaviṟ | paṉṉiṟa mālait tokaipaka lāmpal viḷakkiruḷiṉ | tuṉṉaṟa vuykkumil lōrun tuyiluṟ ṟuṟaivarmikka | koṉṉiṟa vēloṭu vantiṭiṉ ñāḷi kuraitarumē||
Cf. AV161: tāyum nāyum ūrruntuñ cāmai | kāvalar kaṭukutal nilavuveḷip paṭutal | kūkai kuḻaṟutal kōḻikuraṟ kāṭṭuta | lākiya ēḻum allukkuṟit talaivaṉ | varuntoḻiṟ karumai poruntuta lariya ||

The AV categorises this situation slightly differently, grouping it under the wider topic of the 'hero's difficulty in coming'. In pracice though, it seems to either be based upon the AN poem cited above, or both a drawing from a very well established set of obstacles for the hero to overcome.

Cf. PK229 (IAC30, p.148): uravum kaṭalcūḻ ulakuṭai vēntaṉ ucitaṉoṉṉār | paravum kaḻalmaṉṉaṉ kaṉṉiyaṅ kāṉaṟ pakaliṭamnī | varavu makiḻntilaḷ taiyalvey yāṉpōy malaimaṟainta | iravum varaveṉṉa ūṉama tāmniṉ tiṉṉaruṭkē||

Cf. AN118.5-10 (IAC30, p.149): iyalmuru koppiṉai vayanāy piṟpaṭap | pakalvariṟ keḷavai añcucutum ikalkoḷa | irumpiṭi kaṉṟoṭu viraiik kayavāyp | peruṅkai yāṉai kōṭpiḻait tarīi | aṭumpuli vaḻaṅkum āṟiruḷ naṭunāḷ | taṉiyai varutal ataṉiṉum añcutum |
Cf. TK261.3-4: ...puri meṉkuḻa vāṭiṟat taiyameyyē | paḻiyām pakalvari ṉīyira vētum payaṉillaiyē||
Cf. KT246.3-4: pāṉāṭ ṭaṉittōr | tērvantu peyarnta teṉpa vataṟkoṇ | ṭōru malaikku maṉṉai piṟarum |
Cf. AN20.12-16: ...aṉṉai | kaṭikoṇ ṭaṉaḷē tōḻi peruntuṟai | yellaiyu miravu meṉṉātu kalleṉa | valava ṉāyanta vaṇpari | nilavumaṇaṟ koṭkumōr tēruṇ ṭeṉavē ||

Cf. PK236 (IAC30, p.151): aṉṉāy nernal nikaḻntatu kēḷayal vēṅtiṟaiñcum | poṉṉār kaḻalneṭu māṟaṉ kumariyam pūmpoḻilvāy | miṉṉār maṇineṭun tērkaṅkul vantoṉṟu mīṇṭatuṇṭāl | eṉṉā mukañcivan temmaiyum nōkkiṉaḷ emmaṉaiyē||
Cf. TK256.2-4: ... malleḻiṟ kāṉa laraiyiraviṉ | vaṇṇaṉ maṇineṭun tērvanta tuṇṭā meṉacciṟitu | kaṇṇuñ civantaṉṉai yeṉṉaiyu nōkkiṉaḷ kārmayilē||

Cf. PK237 (IAC30, p.151): paṇivar collikaṇ ṭāḷteṉṉaṉ pāḻip pakaitaṇitta | maṇivar cīrmaṉṉaṉ vāḷneṭu māṟaṉ malayameṉṉum | ciṇivar kuṉṟat taruviceṉ ṟāṭiyor vēṅkaiyiṉkīḻk | kaṇivar kātaṟ piṭiyoṭu niṉṟa karuṅkaḷiṟē||

Cf. TK257: vāṉṟōy poḻileḻiṉ māṅkaṉi mantiyiṉ vāykkaṭuvaṉ | tēṉṟōyt tarutti makiḻvakaṇ ṭāṭiru nīṇmuṭimēl | mīṉṟōy puṉaṟpaṇṇai vaittuṭai yāḷaiyu mēṉivattāṉ | nāṉṟōy matiṟṟillai mānakar pōlum varivaḷai||
The TK poem replaces elephants with monkeys but is otherwise similar.
Cf. TK135.2: vaḻiyu matuvaṉṉai yeṉṉiṉ makiḻumvan tentaiyuniṉ | moḻiyiṉ vaḻiniṟkuñ cuṟṟamuṉ ṉēvayam

One can see that the TK has a lightly different organisation to the TNVC. The idea in many earlier poems in the TK, where the confidante refuses the hero's requests to come for a tryst, is that the hero ought to marry the heroine.
Cf. TK251.2-4: ... vāṉakañcēr | arampaiyar tammiḷa mōvaṉṟi vēḻatti ṉeṉpunaṭṭa | kurampaiyar tammiṭa mōviṭan tōṉṟumik kuṉṟiṭattē||

This TK poem is almost a precursor in the sequence to the poem in the TNVC. It asks the question whether the heroine's resting place is that of the gods, whereas in the TNVC the hero has confirmed that he now knows that she is human like him and therefore approachable for marriage.
